beats.label: HOOK + PROMISE
beats.narration: Should you race Gravel del Fuego? I rated 328 gravel races on 14 dimensions. Gravel del Fuego scored 53 out of 100. Solid tier. Here's what that actually means for your season.
beats.text_on_screen: Should You Race Gravel del Fuego?
beats.editing_note: STATE THE PREMISE IN 8 SECONDS. Clear value prop: 'I rated 328 races. Here's where this one lands.' This is the 8-second decision window. Viewers who stay past 15s are 58% more likely to finish.
beats.psych_mechanism: Curiosity gap (specific) + IKEA effect (viewer predicts the tier before reveal).

beats.label: THE COURSE
beats.narration: Gravel del Fuego. Patagonia, Chile. 100 mi. Patagonian mountain gravel.
beats.text_on_screen: Gravel del Fuego | Patagonia, Chile | 100 mi
beats.editing_note: Let the course breathe. Show the route map, then cut to terrain-specific B-roll. This is the SETUP phase — grounding the viewer before the data analysis. Pacing: 25-40 sec cuts.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Top 8
beats.narration: Let's go through the scores. Adventure. 5 out of 5. Type-two fun guaranteed. Type-one fun optional. Course traverses Campo de Hielo Sur borders, passes Grey Glacier, crosses Strait of Magellan by ferry, and reaches King Penguin Reserve in Tierra del Fuego. Experience. 5 out of 5. Once-in-a-lifetime course experience. Puerto Natales to Caleta María through Campo de Hielo Sur is the end of the world stuff. Length. 4 out of 5. Double-digit hours are on the table. The 250K Baqueanos route has an 18-hour cutoff, while the 1000K expedition allows 6. Technicality. 3 out of 5. Technical enough to thin the pack. Course passes through Torres del Paine National Park, Cueva del Milodón, and reaches Caleta María via dirt roads and Patagonian steppe. Elevation. 3 out of 5. Proper climbing. You'll earn your descents. 8000ft over 100 miles averages 80ft per mile — nothing crazy by mountain standards but enough to matter when Patagonian weather turns. Value. 3 out of 5. Fair value. You get what you pay for. Starting at $180 USD for access to some of the most remote terrain on Earth isn't highway robbery. Climate. 2 out of 5. Weather cooperates more often than not. Historical weather data shows average highs of 70°F and lows of 50°F, with a 10% chance of rain on any given day. Altitude. 2 out of 5. Negligible altitude effect. Puerto Natales sits near sea level with the route climbing through Torres del Paine to higher elevations, but no maximum altitude data published.
beats.editing_note: PROGRESSIVE RHYTHM: start tight (15-20 sec per dimension), slow down for the most interesting scores (30-40 sec). Each score: number appears, brief pause, explanation. Avatar reacts to extreme scores (5/5 = chef_kiss, 1/5 = facepalm). RE-ENGAGEMENT at 3:00 mark: insert a surprising score reveal or a meme reaction to break the pattern.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Also Scored
beats.narration: The remaining six. Quick-fire. Prestige. 2 out of 5. Building a name. Not there yet. Race Quality. 2 out of 5. Basic but functional. Gets the job done. Community. 2 out of 5. Some community spirit. Nothing organized. Field Depth. 2 out of 5. Modest field. Some fast riders in the mix. Logistics. 1 out of 5. You are the aid station. Expenses. 1 out of 5. Budget-friendly. Your bank account barely notices.
